question: Consider the following logical statement: ~(P ∧ Q) → (R ∨ S). Show, using logical equivalences, that this statement is logically equivalent to (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S). You may use the following logical equivalences: Material Implication: P → Q ≡ ~P ∨ Q; De Morgan's Laws: ~(P ∧ Q) ≡ ~P ∨ ~Q and ~(P ∨ Q) ≡ ~P ∧ ~Q; Double Negation: ~(~P) ≡ P.
answer:
To show that ~(P ∧ Q) → (R ∨ S) is logically equivalent to (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S), I'll apply logical equivalence laws step-by-step:

Step 1: Start with ~(P ∧ Q) → (R ∨ S)

Step 2: Apply Material Implication (P → Q ≡ ~P ∨ Q)
~(P ∧ Q) → (R ∨ S) ≡ ~(~(P ∧ Q)) ∨ (R ∨ S)

Step 3: Apply Double Negation (~~P ≡ P)
~(~(P ∧ Q)) ∨ (R ∨ S) ≡ (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S)

Therefore, ~(P ∧ Q) → (R ∨ S) ≡ (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S)

The logical equivalence is established by applying material implication followed by double negation.
